comments.commentBody:
I live in the Bay Area and watched live news coverage beginning at about 5 pm.
It was picked up by the local news about 2.5 hours into his climb. The 'people' waiting on the top ledge for him were San Francisco firefighters, who were called in the event they had to affect a rescue. The firefighters helped him tape the flag to the glass and then he shook their hands. Only in San Francisco...!

Tech Museum of Innovaion in San Jose is a major West coast attraction.  Mountain View's 700 acre Shoreline Park with its 50 acre lake and aquatic center is about a mile from Googleplex.  How did the writer miss it?

Alan wrote: " in which the chorus is given a marking of ppppp....I thought on seeing it that Verdi was trying to get the singers' attention and let them know that, at this point in the music..." ...he really REALLY needed to use the "Gents"?
tsk tsk patricia...i bet they don't publish this one...
Given the insanity of our times and the number of violent wars we are engaged in, this seems like an understandable act of protest, statement and theater. Bravo SpiderDan!

The finale of Tchaikovsky's 6th ends with a pppppp marking. I saw Michael Tilson Thomas get apoplectic at a San Francisco Symphony performance with the usual morons who burst into applause the millisecond the piece is over, because he was only at ppp with quite a bit of diminuendo to go when the ovation started. He stormed offstage and refused to return.

The bit that always wakes people up in that sympony is a movement that ends pppp/ppppp, followed immediately by a brassy ff. Not subtle but very effective.

Once again, Obama comes across as lukewarm and uninspiring. Contrast this with Roosevelt's programs like the Rural Electrification Agency, TVA and Bonneville and Hoover Dam, all revenue producing projects. The REA paid for itself with guaranteed loans with a less than 1% default rate. Here's an example of what a modern synergistic Roosevelt program might look like by using the railroads as a basis of an integrated program, putting thousands to work, and benefitting the environment, energy independence, balance of payments, homeland security and a host of other issues. It's published in the Russian River Times and online at:

http://somewhatlogically.com/?p=60

The other thing to point out is that we also got some really great songs and art out of Roosevelt's programs, including Pete' Seeger's "Roll on Columbia". You can look at some of the REA posters at:

http://www.smecc.org...

Perhaps Bruce Springsteen can give us a modern musical equivalent and Shepard Fairey, who did the original Obama poster, might give us some hope filled artwork, but he has to promise not to copy.

This is not news, and Rahm is not the one "pushing for this".
Obama promised this in his "Blueprint for Change" document during the primaries. See page 11.
Did no one in America read this document? Why is everyone so surprised at what Obama is doing, and the agenda he's pushing?
Read his manifesto and judge for yourself. He told America EXACTLY what he was going to do.... in writing.... and he's going down his blueprint like a checklist ticking off the items...... WAKE UP AMERICA!
www.barackobama.com...

From Page 11:
New Jobs through National Infrastructure Investment
Barack Obama and Joe Biden believe that it is critically important for the United States to rebuild its national transportation infrastructure – its highways, bridges, roads, ports, air, and train systems – to strengthen user safety, bolster our long-term competitiveness and ensure our economy continues to grow. Investing in national infrastructure is especially important in our efforts to bolster our homeland security to meet international terrorism and natural disaster threats.
Create a National Infrastructure Reinvestment Bank: Barack Obama and Joe Biden will address the infrastructure challenge by creating a National Infrastructure Reinvestment Bank to expand and enhance, not supplant, existing federal transportation investments. This independent entity will be directed to invest in our nation’s most challenging transportation infrastructure needs. The Bank will receive an infusion of federal money, $60 billion over 10 years, to provide financing to transportation infrastructure projects across the nation. These projects will create up to two million new direct and indirect jobs and stimulate approximately $35 billion per year in new economic activity.

Comments so far raise several questions.

1) inspired by Tudor #2 and frobozzz #6: can the cannon be pointing any direction for this puzzle to work?

2) Hans #3 poses a terrific question. Say the trampoline is gigantic. An infinite reflective plane. Now what angles are possible? For example, with the cannon at 45° the trampoline could be at 45° (one bounce) or 22.5° (two bounces). How does the series continue?

3) Say the cannon is at 45°. You fasten Hans' gigantic trampoline to the mouth of the cannon. At 45° the trampoline creates a ramp. The cannonball rolls up and back. Zero bounces. At what angle will the cannonball return after one bounce? Two? At what point does the cannonball bounce up the trampoline then roll back (not bounce) to the cannon?

4) For the original puzzle as well as its variations: what if the cannonball isn't required to return along its original path?
You gotta love Rex

Brilliant.

The one thing the Jets had in their favor was opening day. If they chose not to leave a roster spot open for Revis, he would be done for the year.

Time was the 12th man.

Rex throwing his weight around, waiting until the pressure on both sides was almost unbearable, no doubt caused Revis to tell his people to find a number and pull the trigger.

Plus the very real possibility that nobody on that side would get paid a penny this year.

Sobering thought.

I will of course acknowledge that I did not think it would get done, but Revis admitted that he wants to stay a Jet, and ultimately that allowed him to agree to a slot that makes much more sense for the Jets than his initial demands did.

If the numbers being reported are accurate he will average less than 12m/yr and that is a job well done by the Jets, and I'm quite sure that Revis could have had a deal that looked a lot like this at any point along the way.

So, kudos to Revis for manning up and accepting that his initial stance was untenable. Kudos to the Jets for proving that they weren't insane to hold theit ground.

Let's agree that everybody wins here.
Dad on his tardy appearance for Saturday Dim Sum "An old woman ran into my car!"
Very happy to read this. Even a decade ago, this type of information would have been difficult for the average fan to get. That internet has its benefits.
Marigenous l  Under the boardwalk; down by the sea!

The Hotel de l'alma was a great stay for me, 2 minutes away from the eiffel tower. The Hotel is really service oriented, which is very nice in paris. The Hotel had a special deal for a 3 night stay minimum aswell on their site: www.alma-paris-hotel.com. I strongly recommend this hotel for its location and services.

We stayed at the Hotel Ampere this summer which has just a hidden hotel in Paris. Its a 4 star hotel with very interesting rates, there is also a restaurant in the hotel. But what we really enjoyed was the fact that to get around paris it was so easy from the hotel. I do recommend this hotel for any going to paris: www.parishotelampere.com

The Hotel des Chevalier, resentlly new as the Hostellerie du Marais, http://www.hostelleriedumarais.com/, is an hotel that mix perfectly modern and tradition. My room was fully renovated, and was the hidden treasure of the hotel. The bedding was beautiful done and comfortable of course.
I didn’t stay a lot in the hotel thought, the area of the Marais is so lovely, you just want to see it all. The buildings, the shops everything was delightful!!! All in all the staff was professional and warm, exactly what you need!
I had no regrets, and for sure will book again...

That's because you're not explaining it right. Economic activity is a CIRCULATION, and it's a circulation that can fall well below where it could be considering all the technology installed and the skill set of the population. This is where we're at.

Now since corporations have made a virtue out of dropping employees at the drop of a hat - where they used to keep them around in bad times for when the economy improved - we've got an automatic (and ARTIFICIAL) collapse in demand, so now the government has to step in and inject money into the economy to get it circulating again.

(I compare this to a bank run - except instead of grabbing all the money, you're shedding all the jobs you can no longer afford to pay out for. And since you fear your competitors will probably do the same thing, you're all caught up in a classic 'prisoner's dilemma'. Here, if NOBODY acts in that manner then EVERYONE is better off, yet if only a FEW PEOPLE act in that way, those who DID come out ahead, and those who DIDN'T get left holding the bag. So since nobody wants to be left holding the bag, everyone does it - so you get the WORST possible outcome for everyone.)

When you understand all this, then talk about 'virtue' and the 'economy naturally resetting' goes away because there's no room for it.
Bring us home some candy and postcards.
That's one of my desert island movies.  No kidding.  Have a safe trip.  Send photos.
Oh ya, when I go to London I stay at a place just a couple of blocks from 'The Coal Hole', but we always have our pints at 'The Harp'.
Welcome to Summers', Geithner's and Bernanke's model.
Welcome to Japan! The music clip is one of my favorite ones. Thank you. Wonder whether you would be in Tokyo and perhaps have some public events?

In today's column, you say the exit from the Great Depression was accidental because the spending that led to more than full employment could not have been conjured up without the war. But, was the war, or perhaps its timing, not a consequence of the economic depression? Would Hitler have come so easily to power without economic discontent?

Food riots are beginning again as a result of climate problems http://www.nytimes.com... Could there be a new Hitler out there seeing opportunity in the nexus of climate with economic recession?
Funny, Professor.  You better stay here and work on a comprehensive economic plan.
So you're planning to teach them proper song and dance, aren't you?
